metadata.title: 3D Hierarchical nano-flake/micro-flower iron fluoride with hydration water induced tunnels for secondary lithium battery cathodes

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoen
3D Hierarchical nano-flake/micro-flower iron fluoride with hydration water induced tunnels for secondary lithium battery cathodes
Ying Baia,⁎,1, Xingzhen Zhoua,1, Chun Zhanb,1, Lu Mac,f, Yifei Yuanb,d, Chuan Wua,e, Mizi Chena, Guanghai Chena, Qiao Nia, Feng Wua,e, Reza Shahbazian-Yassard, Tianpin Wuf, Jun Lub,⁎, Khalil Amineb,⁎
a Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, PR China b Chemical Sciences and Engineering Division, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South, Cass Avenue, Lemont, IL 60439, USA c Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Ohio State University, 100 West 18th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210, USA d Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago, 845 West Taylor Street, Chicago, IL 60607, USA e Collaborative Innovation Center of Electric Vehicles in Beijing, Beijing 100081, PR China f X-ray Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, USA
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Lithium ion batteries Cathode materials Iron fluoride Liquid precipitation Hydration water
A B S T R A C T
As a potential multi-electron electrode material for next generation lithium ion batteries, iron fluoride (FeF3) and its analogues are attracting much more attentions. Their microstructures are the key to achieve good electrochemical performances. In this work, FeF3·3H2O nano-flakes precursor with high crystallinity and flower-like morphology is synthesized successfully, by a liquid precipitation method using Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and NH4HF2 as raw materials. The formation and the crystal growth mechanisms of the FeF3·3H2O precursors are investigated and discussed. After different temperature heat-treatment and followed by ball-milling with Super P, the as-prepared FeF3.0·33H2O/C and FeF3/C nanocomposites are used as cathode materials for lithium ion batteries. The FeF3.0·33H2O/C nanocomposite exhibits a noticeable initial specific capacity of 187.1 mAh g −1 and reversible specific capacity of 172.3 mAh g−1 at .1 C within a potential range of 2.0–4.5 V. The capacity retention is as high as 97.33% after 50 cycles. Combined with HRTEM test, it confirms that the hydration water is not harmful but useful, namely, the tunnel phase formed with the hydration water is crucial to unobstructed Li+ diffusion, and therefore leading to excellent electrochemical performances.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the last two decades, lithium ion battery (LIB) has been playing a more and more important role in energy supplying for portable electronic products and energy storage, for its advantages in efficiency, environmental benignity, cost and safety [1–5]. In spite of the several breakthroughs in the chemical of cathode materials, the theoretical gravimetric capacities of commercial cathode materials are still insufficient for practical applications such as the electric vehicles and grid-level energy storage [6–8]. In order for higher capacity of the LIB cathode, various new forms of energy storage materials are investigated, and the multi-electron materials have drawn more and more attention due to their high theoretical specific capacities [9]. Among them, iron fluoride is very attractive because of its high specific capacity (237 mAh g−1 per electron transfer), high operating voltage,
non-toxicity and low-cost [10,11]. FeF3 was reported as the cathode materials for lithium ion batteries as early as 1997. It showed a high-voltage charge-discharge behavior but delivered a reversible capacity of only 80 mAh g−1 in a discharge voltage region from 2 V to 4.5 V at a low rate, which was far below the theoretical capacity [12]. In fact, the actual capacity of FeF3 is reduced largely by its poor electronic and ionic conductivity [13–15]. In order to improve the electrochemical performance of FeF3, many methods have been introduced, such as FeF3/carbon composite prepared by high energy milling with conductive agents [13–17], nanofabrication [18–22], thin films obtained by Pulsed Laser Deposition technique [23–25], in site coating [26,27], metal doping [28,29] and so on. Among all of them, high energy milling with conductive agents is a simple and effective method as the grain size can be significantly reduced with the conductive network established at the same time [30].
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2016.12.017 Received 6 September 2016; Received in revised form 4 December 2016; Accepted 9 December 2016
⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contribute equally to this work. E-mail addresses: membrane@bit.edu.cn (Y. Bai), junlu@anl.gov (J. Lu), amine@anl.gov (K. Amine).
Nano Energy 32 (2017) 10–18
Available online 10 December 2016 2211-2855/ © 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
MARK
As a result, the Li+ diffusion pathways within particles are shortened and the electronic transportation is facilitated significantly.
Iorn fluorides exist with different chemical compositions, either with or without hydration water, for instance, FeF3, FeF3.0·33H2O, FeF3·3H2O, FeF2·4H2O, etc. It is generally accepted that moisture should be restrictly avoided in lithium ion batteries, because water is highly reactive towards carbonate-based electrolyte as well as metallic lithium, and the as-generated by-products will degrade the electrode materials. However, it is interesting that most of these hydrous iorn fluorides have electrochemical activities. Therefore, it is of great importance to understand what is the role of hydration water, and why hydration water will not act like the moisture.
In previous works, there are various methods to synthesize the ironbased fluoride materials, for instance, liquid-precipitate method [28,31–34], evaporation method [35], sol-gel method [36] and solvothermal method [28,30,37,38]. Toxic HF is the most commonly used fluoride source in these methods, which may lead to some safety issues [18,31–33,35–37,39,40]. Besides, some ionic-liquids was also applied as fluoride source but its high cost should be a concern for industry application [19,21,38,41]. In fact, solution chemistry is a good approach, because it can build an suitable environment full of water, which can be easily introduced into the lattice of the as-prepared iron fluoride. Therefore, a liquid-precipitate method is applied in the present study, where NH4HF2 is selected as fluoride source, because it is less volatilizable and safer than HF. Moreover, the gaseous product of NH4HF2 is expected to form porous structures for the as-prepared particles. FeF3·3H2O precursor with flower-like morphology is prepared through this approach. Active FeF3.0·33H2O/C nanocomposites were obtained after calcination at different temperatures and the subsequent ball-milling with Super P. The impacts of composition and crystal structure on the electrochemical performance of the FeF3.0· 33H2O/C nanocomposite are discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample synthesis
sections.text:
All chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used as received without any further purification. Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and NH4HF2 were selected as raw materials and the polyethylene glycol (PEG 20000) was used as a dispersant. The preparation process is showed in Scheme 1. Firstly, PEG (15g)) was dissolved in a co-solvent of ethanol (150 ml) and deionized water (20 ml) in duplicate. One was added to Fe(NO3)3
ethanol solution (160 ml, .25 mol L−1); the other was transferred to a Teflon ware, and then a required amount of NH4HF2 powder was dissolved in it. With peristaltic pump, the Fe(NO3)3 solution was added drop-wise to NH4HF2 solution accompanying by stirring. After 12 h′ standing time, pale yellow precipitates were obtained. Washed by deionized water and ethanol alternately for three times, the precipitates were vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 12 h and cooled down naturally. In order to control its hydration water content, the as-prepared precursor was then calcined at various temperatures from 200 to 500 °C, and the obtained samples were named as S200, S300, S400, S500, respectively. The calcined iron fluoride samples and synthesis conditions are listed in Table S1. To further improve the conductivity of the calcined iron fluoride sample, a conductive agent, namely Super P, was added (iron fluoride: SP=85:15 by weight). After high energy ball-milling at 300 rpm for 3 h, the mixture was converted into an iron fluoride/ carbon nanocomposite, as shown in Scheme 1 and Table S1. The final products were named as S200/SP, S300/SP, S400/SP, S500/SP, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Structural characterization
sections.text: To understand the thermal stability of the precursor, and select suitable calcine temperature, TG-DTA was conducted with a Seiko 6300 instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 700 °C under argon atmosphere. The crystal structures of the as-synthesized materials were collected on a Rigaku 2400 XRD with Cu Kα radiation (λ=.15418 nm) between 10° and 80° 2θ at a scan rate of 8° 2θ min−1. The morphologies were investigated by using a FEI Quanta 250 FESEM. The HRTEM was done using a JEOL 3010 equipped with a 300 kV LaB6 electron source. The atomic modeling was established using Crystal Maker software.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical evaluation
sections.text:
The nanocomposites were mixed with Super P and a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder at a weight ratio of 8:1:1 in N-methyl-1-2pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent. The as-obtained slurry was then coated on an aluminum foil and vacuum-dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The laminate was punched into disks with a diameter of 11 mm as cathode electrodes and the areal density is about 1.0 mg/cm2. Lithium foil was used as the counter electrode and reference electrode; the electrolyte was 1 M solution of LiPF6 dissolved in a mixed solvent of ethylene carbonate (EC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and ethylene methyl carbonate (EMC) (1:1:1 by volume). The coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box, using a porous polypropylene Celgard 2400 as separator. All cells were aged for 12 h before testing.
Charge/discharge tests were performed with a CT2001A instrument to evaluate the electrochemical capacities. The CV experiments and EIS were conducted with a CHI604D electrochemical workstation. CV tests were measured at a scanning rate of .1 mV s−1 between 2.0 and 4.5 V. The frequency range was from 106 Hz to 10−1 Hz at potentiostatic signal amplitudes of 5 mV.
The X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) measurements for the Fe K-edge (7112 eV) were completed in transmission mode on the bending-magnet beamline of the Advanced Phono Source (9-BM-C) in Argonne National Laboratory. The incident beam was monochromatized by using a Si (111) fixed-exit, double-crystal monochromator. In situ XAS experiments were made on the coin cells with a window of 5 mm diameter sealed with 50-μm-thick Kapton tape. The cells were cycled with a MACCOR cycler. XANES data reduction followed standard methods using the ATHENA software package.Scheme 1. The sketch map of the preparation route of different iron fluoride samples.

sections.heading: 3.1. Crystal structure and morphology
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows morphology and X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the precursor. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images revealed that the precursor nano-flakes have thicknesses about 50–100 nm and the flakes form beautiful flower-like shapes (Fig. 1a-b). It can be clearly seen that the diffraction peaks of precursor match well with FeF3·3H2O (tetragonal structure, P4/n space group, JCPDS 32-0464), without impurity peaks observed (Fig. 1c).
To understand the self-assembly process of the FeF3·3H2O precursor, the apparent morphologies of the particles at different aging time were recorded, as shown in Fig. 2. The growing process is visualized by Fig. 2a-f, and the corresponding mechanism is illustrated by Fig. 2g.
The slow assembling process seems to be a two-step procedure, namely, self-template and self-aggregation. At the end of stirring, the morphology of the precipitate is irregular. After standing for 3 h, most of the particles grew a plate shape by themselves and partial selfaggregations have taken place, just as shown in Fig. 2b. The polyethylene glycol (PEG) plays an important role in this step. By adding PEG to the mixture solvent, the viscosity became higher and the fluidity turned lower, which affected the reaction kinetics. As a result, the reactive interface could be increased and the reaction time will be reduced [42], which both sides benefit the growth and formation of FeF3·3H2O crystals. The seeds take a thermodynamically unfavorable plate-like shape, which is a typical case of kinetic-controlled growth [43]. With increasing standing time, the nearby plate crystals adjust themselves to close each other and form interpenetration twin spontaneously and orderly, as shown in Fig. 2c and d. This step is driven by the oriented attachment mechanism [44]. The longer the standing time is, the better the morphology will be. After 12 h, the well-developed flower-like particles are obtained. In addition, with increasing standing time, the edges of the particles become thinner, which are in favor of a well-knit structure. Little difference between Fig. 2e and f was observed, which indicating that the 12 h standing time is just enough.
According to the result of the thermogravimetric - differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), the weight loss of FeF3·3H2O happened in four steps (Fig. S1), including the removal of absorbed water and the phase transformations of crystals, which are explained by reactions (1)–(3). Therefore, the as-prepared precursor was pre-sintered at 120 °C in vacuum oven to remove the absorbed water and then transferred into tube furnace to be calcinated. 200 °C, 300 °C, 400 °C and 500 °C were chosen as the target temperatures and the whole calcining process was in pure argon to avoid the unexpected reaction with oxygen. To distinguish the products well, the calcinated powders were marked as S200, S300, S400 and S500 corresponding to the calcination processes 200 °C (3 h), 200 °C (3 h) - 300 °C (3 h), 200 °C (3 h) - 400 °C (3 h) and 200 °C (3 h) - 500 °C (3 h), respectively. After
being ball milled with Super P (SP), they were reconverted to S200/SP, S300/SP, S400/SP and S500/SP respectively. All the sample names and corresponding synthesis conditions are listed in Table S1.
FeF ∙3H O → FeF ∙0. 33H O + 2. 67H O3 2 3 2 2 (1)
FeF ∙0. 33H O → FeF +0. 33H O3 2 3 2 (2)
2FeF →2FeF + F3 2 2 (3)
The main component of the as-prepared iron fluoride sample changes with increasing calcination temperature, which is indicated by XRD results (Fig. S2). The main phase of S200 is FeF3.0·33H2O, demonstrating reaction (1) has taken place under 200 °C, which is in accordance with the TG-DTA results (Fig. S1). PEG evaporates during the temperature region from 200 °C to 300 °C, which is reflected by SEM (Fig. S3). When the temperature is lower than 250 °C (the boiling point of PEG), most PEG still remain in material, supporting the original morphology (Fig. S3a). However, the particle shape easily changes when the PEG evaporates at 300 °C (Fig. S3b). It is no doubt that S300 is purer than S200. As expected, when the calcination temperature reaches at 400 °C, the crystal phase has changed totally and the main content is converted to FeF3, which can be described by reaction (2). The production of FeF2 also means that reaction (3) is taking place. The main component of S500 remains FeF3, but much Fe2O3 is detected as well as little FeF2. Besides, the material is pulverizing gradually and S500 turns to nanoscale fine particles (Fig. S3c-d). Reaction (3) is responsible for this phenomenon.
Theoretically, with increasing temperature and further decomposition of FeF3, the content of FeF2 should increase as well. However, large amount of Fe2O3 are detected, so it is speculated that the asproduced FeF2 reacts with O2 in air after calcination to become Fe2O3 due to its poor thermodynamic stability, which can be summarized as reaction (4). What's more, when the particle size has been decreased to nanoscale (Fig. S3d), the large specific surface area results in more active sites, and thus promotes the reaction between O2 and FeF2. As a result, it is Fe2O3 rather than FeF2 that is detected obviously in S500.
12FeF + 3O →2Fe O + 8FeF2 2 2 3 3 (4)
The different phases are further verified by the high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) results. Fig. 3 illustrates the atomic scale imaging of the particles after being treat at 300 °C (a, b) and 500 °C (c). The particle in Fig. 3a exhibits a tunneled FeF3.0· 33H2O phase (Cmcm) being viewed along [310] zone axis, as confirmed by the [310] atomic model of the theoretical tunneled FeF3.0·33H2O phase in the inset. The solid yellow balls represent Fe1 (0,.5, 0) and the circular yellow balls stand for Fe2 (.25, .25, 0). Fe2 columns are invisible due to their limited number along [310] direction and the resulted weak scattering contribution to form the final contrast, while Fe1 are visible because they have a dense pack along [310] direction that leads to the final contrast. Overall, the tunnel structure is obvious and can surely facilitate the transportation of Li+. At the same time, we also found FeF3 phase (R-3 h) in S300 sample (Fig. 3b), which
indicated that reaction (2) took place as well. But the concentration of FeF3 is no doubt very low because it cannot be detected by XRD (Fig. S2). Fig. 3c is for the particle after 500 °C treatment, where only the FeF3 phase with R-3h space group is observed. Therefore, treatment at higher temperature is able to improve the phase transition from the tunneled phase FeF3.0·33H2O to the new phase FeF3, while further electrochemical experiments are required to compare the performance
of these two phases. In order to improve conductivity of the material, the powders after calcination were ball milled with Super P to get the nano-composites, as showed in Scheme 1. The SEM images (Fig. S4) show that the particle sizes of the nano composites are around 100–200 nm which is smaller than particles sizes (.1–1.7 µm) after ball milling the rectangular micro-bar and the hollow prism/cylinder at higher rotate speed
(320 rpm) [30,37]. It follows that such 3D micro-flower iron fluoride, self-assembled by about 50–100 nm thick nano-flakes, is more easily ground into nanoparticles through the processes of micro-flower converting into nano-flakes, subsequent into nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
The electrochemical properties of different iron fluoride samples are studied in coin cells employing lithium foil as counter/reference electrode and S200/SP, S300/SP, S400/SP, S500/SP as the working electrodes. The specific capacities are calculated based on the quality of iron fluorides only. S200/SP, S300/SP, S400/SP and S500/SP deliver initial discharge specific capacities of 163.4, 187.1, 198.1 and 170 mAh g−1, respectively (Fig. 4a). Because of the irreversible formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in the first cycle, the specific capacities in the first cycle are not stable [6,29,30,45–47]. The specific capacities in the second cycle are consequently regarded as reversible. Both S300/SP and S400/SP deliver the high reversible capacities. However, with the increase of cycle number, the specific capacity of S400/SP fades fast. As shown in Fig. 4b, the capacity retentions are calculated based on reversible capacities. Four samples seem to be divided into two groups: S200/SP and S300/SP constitute the FeF3.0· 33H2O group (based on the constituent) and the FeF3 group is composed of S400/SP and S500/SP. The capacity retentions of the former group are obviously higher than those of the other group. Herein, the cycling performance of FeF3.0·33H2O is superior to that of FeF3, which is very similar to previous report [37].
To test the rate performances of different samples, the cells are discharge-charged at various current densities from .1 to 1 C and finally back to .1 C (Fig. 4c). S300/SP shows superior rate performances. It exhibits a high initial discharge capacity of 193 mAh g−1, and achieves reversible capacities of 173, 161, 150, and 146 mAh g−1 at
.1 C, .2 C, .5 C and 1.0 C, respectively. The discharge capacity of S300/ SP at 1 C in the voltage range of 2.0–4.5 V is higher than that of FeF3.0· 33H2O/C [30,37] and FeF3.0·33H2O/CMK-3 [48] (about 130 mAh g−1). Superior rate capability of S300/SP can be ascribed to smaller nanocomposites via ball milling nano-flake/micro-flower precursor with SP. Because smaller nanoparticle contributes to shorting the path of electronic and ionic transmission path, resulting in improving the reaction kinetics of Li+ [13,49]. In addition, after an activation process for S300/SP during high-rate cycles, it can achieve a high reversible capacity of 181 mAh g−1 when the discharge rate recovers to 0.1 C.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was conducted to explore the electrochemical behaviors of different iron fluoride samples (Fig. 4d). The EIS plot consist of one semicircle in the high frequency region and a sloping line in the low frequency region. The semicircle reflects the charge transfer resistance (Rct), and the sloping line is related to the diffusion impedance (Zw) of Li
+ in the solid matrix. Fig. S5 demonstrates the corresponding equivalent circuit model in which RΩ represents the impedance of electrolyte. The values of Rct are listed in Table S2. It is shown that Rct of S300/SP is much lower than those of S200/SP, S400/SP and S500/SP, which is in line with the results of capacity retention in Fig. 4b.
In order to determine the oxidation state evolution of the Fe element in the S300/SP electrode, Fe K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra were collected continuously while the cell was under cycling. Fe K-edge XANES were also recorded from FeO and Fe2O3 standards as references for Fe(II) and Fe(III). Fig. 5a and b compared the normalized Fe K-edge XANES spectra during the first discharge and charge. The Fe K-edge of the S300/SP in the beginning is at about 7126 eV which is close to the Fe K-edge of Fe2O3, showing the oxidation state of Fe is +3 in the uncycled electrode. During the discharge, the Fe K-edge shifted to a lower energy due to the reduction
of the Fe(III). At the end of discharge, the Fe K-edge is still higher than Fe(II) in FeO, showing an average oxidization state higher than +2. This result indicates that the Fe(III) was not fully reduced to Fe(II) when discharge to 2 V. In the following charge to 4.5 V, the Fe K-edge shifted gradually back to the about 7126 eV, corresponding to the oxidation of Fe to Fe(III). According to the above result, the discharge process of S300/SP can be declared by reaction (5), which also explains why the specific capacity of S300/SP is less than the theoretical.
OxLi +FeF ·0. 33H O → Li FeF ·0. 33H (x < 1)+ 3 2 x 3 2 (5)
To better illustrate the XANES spectra evolution, 2D contour plots of Fe k-edge XANES spectra recorded during the first two cycles of the cell and the corresponding voltage profile are presented in Fig. 5c and d. The evolution of the XANES spectra, especially the back and forth shift of the edge, is well correlated with discharge-charge process. In the second cycle, the evolution was repeated in a symmetrical pattern corresponding to the symmetrical voltage profile, indicating high reversibility of the electrochemical lithiation/delithiation reactions of the S300/SP during the discharge and charge process. It is corresponding to the good cycle performance of shown in Fig. 4b.
So far, S300/SP shows the best electrochemical properties, but the reasons behind the differences among different samples need discussing. Actually, different electrochemistry properties for the iron fluoride
samples are ascribed to the different compositions of these materials, as displayed in Fig. S2. The active constituent of S200 and S300 is FeF3.0·33H2O while S400 and S500 have already converted to FeF3. Apparently, the traces of hydration water play an important role in the structure and subsequently impact the electrochemical performance.
The structures of FeF3.0·33H2O and FeF3 can help illustrating the impact of hydration water, as shown in Fig. 6. (002) plane of FeF3.0· 33H2O is corresponding to the strongest diffraction peaks of S200 and S300 while (012) plane of FeF3 is corresponding to the strongest diffraction peaks of S400 and S500 (Fig. S2). In the structures of both FeF3.0·33H2O and FeF3, iron atom is surrounded by six fluorine atoms in a form of octahedron [37,50]. The adjacent octahedrons connect with each other, sharing the apices of fluorine atoms. But the connection ways are totally different in FeF3.0·33H2O or FeF3. For FeF3.0·33H2O, six octahedrons are connected via corner-sharing, forming lots of special and huge hexagonal cavities in FeF3.0·33H2O (Fig. 6a). The water molecules are located in the center of cavities to stabilize the structure. The growing of (002) plane forms large inner tunnel structure in FeF3.0·33H2O (Fig. 6c), which can facilitate the insertion and extraction for Li+. As a result, Li+ can be more easily intercalated and extracted during the charge-discharge process in FeF3.0·33H2O, which results in the excellent cycle and rate performances compared with other samples (Fig. 4b-c). Besides, the exis-
tence of hydration water could reduce the ionicity and improve the electronic conductivity significantly [37], which is beneficial to the lower Rct values of S300/SP. Compared with S300/SP, S200/SP shows the inferior specific capacity in spite of the same iron fluoride. It is because that amorphous PEG cannot evaporate at 200 °C and has negative effects on the capacity as an impurity residue.
As for FeF3, it shows a distorted ReO3 structure without the hydration water (Fig. 6b and d). The octahedrons are closer with each other to form narrow tunnel, making Li+ accommodating more difficult. This distinguishes FeF3 from FeF3.0·33H2O in terms of capacity and cycle performance, as shown in Fig. 4. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) results (Fig. S6) and discharge-charge curves (Fig. S7) also demonstrate the differences between FeF3.0·33H2O and FeF3. The CV curves of S200/SP and S300/SP are similar, with only one couple of reversible redox peaks detected, which are related to the lithium ion insertion and extraction process, as declared by reaction (5). However, for S400/SP and S500/SP samples, two pairs of redox peaks are detected obviously after the first scan loop. Both the discharge-charge curves of S200/SP and S300/SP present a discharging platform at ~2.7 V and a charging platform at ~3.2 V. However, the discharge-charge curves of S400/SP and S500/SP both present two discharging platforms at ~3.3 V and ~3.0 V, and corresponding two charging platform at ~3.4 V and ~3.1 V, respectively. Apparently, Li+ prefers to insert into FeF3 step by step, as described in reaction (6) and (7), which coincides with the previous reports [51,52].
xxLi +FeF + e →Li FeF+ 3 − x 3 (6)
yyLi + Li FeF + e → Li FeF (x + y < 1)+ x 3 − x+y 3 (7)
Fe2O3 is responsible for differences between the S400/SP and S500/SP. On one hand, Fe2O3, as a remarkable composition for S500/SP shown in Fig. S2, has higher electronic conductivity than FeF3 [27], which decreases the value of Rct (Fig. 4d). On the other hand, Fe2O3 has no contribute to capacity because the discharge platform of Fe2O3 is not higher than 2 V [53–56], resulting in decreasing of capacity in the voltage region from 2 V to 4.5 V, as shown in Fig. 4(a-c). However, unlike Fe2O3, FeF2/C can deliver a capacity of ~135 mAh g−1 in above voltage region according to our previous study [34], resulting in the better rate performance of S400/ SP than S500/SP. In addition, amorphous PEG cannot evaporate at 200 °C and it would hinder Li+ transport in S200/SP. Thus, better rate capability of S400/SP than S200/SP can be attributed to the poor Li+ transport in S200/SP.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, the FeF3·3H2O precursor with high crystallinity and flower-like morphology can be synthesized by liquid precipitation method, and the self-assembling mechanism has been verified. The active iron fluoride samples can be obtained by heat treatment of the FeF3·3H2O precursor, and followed by high energy ball milling with SP successively. The subsequent electrochemical testing reflects two different reaction mechanisms, corresponding to as-obtained FeF3 or FeF3.0·33H2O at different temperatures. Furthermore, the hydration water in iron fluoride is proven to play an important role in cycling stability of the composite electrode, because it can reduce the ionicity and improve the electronic conductivity, and the inner hexagonal tunnel in FeF3.0·33H2O can facilitate the insertion and extraction for Li+. The optimized FeF3.0·33H2O sample S300/SP achieves a noticeable initial discharge capacity of 187 mAh g−1 as well as excellent cycling and rate performances, which indicates the FeF3.0·33H2O/C composite is a promising cathode material for high capacity rechargeable Li-ion batteries.
In general, moisture should be restrictly avoided in lithium ion batteries due to its high reactivity towards lithium metal and electrolyte. However, this study showed that moderate “crystal“ water is beneficial to construct different tunneled structure of iorn fluoride. Furthermore, the strategy of introducing exogenetic species to adjust the internal tunnel is expected to be an efficient way to design and adjust the structure-function relationship of the desired electrode materials for advanced secondary batteries.

Among them, iron fluoride is very attractive because of its high specific capacity (237 mAh g per electron transfer), high operating voltage, non-toxicity and low-cost [10,11].

In order to improve the electrochemical performance of FeF3, many methods have been introduced, such as FeF3/carbon composite prepared by high energy milling with conductive agents [13–17], nanofabrication [18–22], thin films obtained by Pulsed Laser Deposition technique [23–25], in site coating [26,27], metal doping [28,29] and so on.

In order to improve the electrochemical performance of FeF3, many methods have been introduced, such as FeF3/carbon composite prepared by high energy milling with conductive agents [13–17], nanofabrication [18–22], thin films obtained by Pulsed Laser Deposition technique [23–25], in site coating [26,27], metal doping [28,29] and so on.

Among all of them, high energy milling with conductive agents is a simple and effective method as the grain size can be significantly reduced with the conductive network established at the same time [30].

metadata.abstractText: As a potential multi-electron electrode material for next generation lithium ion batteries, iron fluoride (FeF3) and its analogues are attracting much more attentions. Their microstructures are the key to achieve good electrochemical performances. In this work, FeF3·3H2O nano-flakes precursor with high crystallinity and flower-like morphology is synthesized successfully, by a liquid precipitation method using Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and NH4HF2 as raw materials. The formation and the crystal growth mechanisms of the FeF3·3H2O precursors are investigated and discussed. After different temperature heat-treatment and followed by ball-milling with Super P, the as-prepared FeF3.0·33H2O/C and FeF3/C nanocomposites are used as cathode materials for lithium ion batteries. The FeF3.0·33H2O/C nanocomposite exhibits a noticeable initial specific capacity of 187.1 mAh g −1 and reversible specific capacity of 172.3 mAh g at .1 C within a potential range of 2.0–4.5 V. The capacity retention is as high as 97.33% after 50 cycles. Combined with HRTEM test, it confirms that the hydration water is not harmful but useful, namely, the tunnel phase formed with the hydration water is crucial to unobstructed Li diffusion, and therefore leading to excellent electrochemical performances.
